revision.comment: moved [[The Computer Revolution/Introduction/Entertainment]] to [[The Computer Revolution/Entertainment]]: Move to open chapter position.
revision.text:
Delivery of entertainment - online, high tech effects, easy access forms of entertainment - shopping, movies, music (MP3), games, magazines, tabliods, newspapers, instant alerts, email, messenger (MSN), webcams, netmeetings (video conferencing),
[[Category:The Computer Revolution]]

Computers have come a long way in the entertainment/music area. We have watched music evolve from the record album to the 8 track players to cassettes and now compact discs (CD's) and portable media players (PMP). We can either play CD's on the computer or download music from the internet. Years ago we used to use an engine called Napster to download music. Now we have engines like 'Limewire' (file sharing software) where we do not have to pay to download music.
We have the option to either rip songs from existing CD's onto new blank CD's or download music from the internet and burn songs onto a CD. There are other options we can use which are downloading onto MP3 players or iPods. A portable multimedia player, or PMP is a hard disk or flash memory based electronic device, such as an "MP3 player", which is capable of storing and playing files in one or more media formats. MP3 format is a compression system for music. The MP3 format helps reduce the number of bytes in a song without hurting the quality of the song's sound. With MP3, a 32 megabyte (MB) song on a CD compresses to about 3 MB. This lets you download a song in minutes rather than hours, and store hundreds of songs on your hard disc without taking up much space. The main attraction of portable media players is often their versatility: being able to load and play different formats of video (including MPEG, DivX, and XviD), audio (including MP3, WAV, and Ogg Vorbis), or digital images, (including BMP, JPEG, and GIF). Some even count some Handheld game consoles like sony's PSP and GamePark Holdings' GP2X as being a PMP for their media playing capabilities. [http://computer.howstuffworks.com/mp31.htm| http://computer.howstuffworks.com/mp31.htm]
A portable video player is a type of portable media player which focuses on the playback of digital video. Some portable media players can store and display digital images. In this instance the Apple 5th-generation iPod could be considered a portable media player- as it is capable of playing back audio as well as displaying digital pictures and video. Also the Creative Zen Vision:M is another player that can play both audio and video, picks up FM Radio and records voice as well as the larger screened (2.5" to 4" respectively) Zen Vision. The Sony HMP-A1, released only in Japan and Europe, had these same capabilities as well as longer battery life. The Samsung Yepp YP-T8 also provided these capabilities, as well as voice, FM radio, and line recording. It also included a USB host capability for link up to other portable devices without the use of a PC. Some other examples of portable media players with these capabilities include the Archos Gmini series, aigo E-858, X2 MegaView series, the Neuros 442, the iriver series of media players, the Olympus m:robe, the acclaimed iStation v43, MP4 Star by Intechip Corp. and the Cowon A2. MSI developed and showcased the first solar powered player, the MSI MEGA 540, at CeBIT in Hannover, Germany [1]. Other portable media players combine a focus on recording capability with playback features, for example the Neuros Recorder 2 records as well as plays back several audio and video formats.
The bundled software used for transferring music, photos and videos is called iTunes. As a music jukebox application, iTunes stores a comprehensive library of music on the user's computer and can play, burn and rip music from a CD. The most recent version of iTunes has photo and video synchronization features. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portable_media_player
The iPod is currently the world's best-selling digital audio player, and its worldwide mainstream adoption makes it one of the most popular consumer brands.
It will be interesting to see what the future holds for music technology.
[[Category:The Computer Revolution]]
We have come a long way from playing music from the early days only on vinyl, 8 tracks, or cassette form. Now of days you can enjoy listening to music on CD’s through the computer using Windows Media Player by default or downloading them to your favorite MP3 Player. If Windows Media Player doesn’t want to play for any reason like in Windows 7 with the newer version of Windows Media Player 12 because of the darn wma server execution error, you can use any of the following players to play your music that include ACE Mega Codecs Pack, Banshee, ITunes, Nero, Overdrive Media Console, QuickTime Player, Real Player, Rhapsody, Winamp, and VLC Player to name a few. If you want to purchase a CD you can listen to it first before purchasing a disc you would hate spending $20 for it. You can use several sites on the internet to check them out. My favorite websites include YouTube, MySpace, Kazaa, Rhapsody, Napster, or ITunes. The best website to my knowledge for the past two years being visually impaired and works the best with accessibility software such as JAWS and Zoom Text is Kazaa. Even though it’s a paid subscription for $19.99 a month you get unlimited downloads of the entire collection to play through Windows Media Player or Winamp. Plus you can download unlimited ringtones of the tracks to your cell phone for free since it is a part of the subscription. I have thrown away my package to my cell company since they were charging 3.00 for 1 ringtones at a time.
Media Players are software programs for playing multimedia files, audio or video on your computer. Windows has various types of free downloadable devices you can choose from. You can create your own library of playlists by purchasing music through ITunes and transferring them to a cd. I like purchasing the music because you just buy the songs you really like. These playlists allow you to burn cd’s or watch dvd’s. You can also stream music on your computer (listening) while working on files or documents. I found that out this year when I wanted to listen to music but didn’t have a small radio or cd player. This is a nice feature and I don’t normally use media players. My husband has burned cd’s for our car cd player using this. But you have to be careful because of copyright laws, do not do this to sell music. It hurts the artists and record companies who are trying to sell their music.

==Netmeetings== *Applications sharing and data conferencing- Unlike most conferencing products, which enable only audio phone calls, NetMeeting allows users to have a much richer experience by sharing information on their PC with the people they are talking to, allowing to connect with multiple users. *Allows sharing of of one's desktop with multiple users with a choice of letting the other users edit it. *The other users in the conference do not have to have the same application to view it. *Netmeeting also allows users to share a whiteboard, where they sketch their ideas, as well as live chat with the rest of the conference. * NetMeeting will change the way people communicate and collaborate on the Internet and corporate intra-nets by expanding the situations in which the PC can be used. Possible scenarios include these: -'''''Virtual meetings''''', allowing users to be remote or in different locations and conduct meetings as if everyone were in the same room.
-'''''Document collaboration''''', allowing users to work together and collaborate on documents or information in real time.
-'''''Customer service''''', allowing users to communicate directly with customer service from a Web site, or be able to see graphic information as part of a telephone call.
-'''''Telecommuting''''', allowing users to extend their reach while on the road or other locations beyond file sharing or e-mail, by taking advantage of data conferencing capabilities.
-'''''Distance learning''''', allowing presentations or information to be presented to numerous people at the same time over the Internet or intra-nets for education purposes.
==Key features and benefits== *NetMeeting makes it easy to connect and communicate with friends and family over the Internet. *NetMeeting extends the telephone call to enable rich multimedia communication. *NetMeeting lets users get the most out of their PC on the Internet. *Increase in the productivity of end users. *Reduction of the cost of support on intra-nets. *Extend conferencing to products, solutions and services.
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: cleanup; don't like the anecdote though
revision.text:
== The Computer Revolution as a Business Tool == Computers are an indispensable tool for doing business. This is the plain truth that all businesses large or small must understand. When I was a kid, on allowance day, I'd cycle over to Mr. Lee's candy store and buy 25 cents of mixed candy. Mr. Lee knowing how much I preferred the sugar coated strawberries to those mini-tootsie rolls would fill the order (a little brown bag) top heavy with those delicious strawberries, a smattering of other sweets, and at the most one or two tootsie rolls. Unlike the competition up the street at the Blue Jeans candy store where no matter how you protested the order was always filled with goodies in equal amounts, Mr. Lee understood the business principle of customization. In fact, I'm sure that if Mr. Lee were doing business today, he would be keeping track of his customer's buying habits with a computer like so many successful businesses are doing.
Consider this: When you shop at retailers like Superstore, Home Depot, Staples and so on, virtually all of the products on the shelf are there in an attempt to fit the shopper’s tastes. How do these retailers know the shopping habits of thousands people? Simple, they are tracking and recording purchases at the check out counter with a computer. More sophisticated software programs will record demographics like age, address, sex, occupation, and how much money you spend.
But computers don't just help record customer purchases. They are critical in managing inventories of literally thousands of products. This aids retailers in deciding how much and when to replenish there stocks; what is selling like hotcakes and what isn’t moving.
Perhaps most important of all, computers can track the flow of money. Accounting applications like Excel and Quicken allow retailers to keep record of debits and credits, profits and losses, charitable donations, and theft. They are useful for keeping the all important tax records too. Computers streamline business and keep costs down while enabling faster and more efficient service.
{{BookCat}}

Thanks for experimenting with the page [[:Stuffed Camel]] on Wikibooks. Your test worked, and has been reverted or removed. Please use [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|the sandbox]] for any other tests you want to do. Take a look at the [[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome page]] if you would like to learn more about contributing to our project. Thanks.<!-- Test-n (first level warning) --> ''If this is an IP address, and it is shared by multiple users, ignore this warning if you did not make any [[Wikipedia:vandalism|unconstructive]] edits.'' [[User:Az1568|Az1568]] 02:43, 6 September 2006 (UTC)

Hello Areil123, welcome to wikibooks! I see that you and several other new users have been working on the [[The Computer Revolution]] book. Is this part of some kind of class or project? If so, who is in charge?
Anyway, my name is [[User:Whiteknight|Whiteknight]], and I am a wikibookian. I would be willing to help you and your friends if you would like. Feel free to send me a message [[User talk:Whiteknight|on my user talk page]] if you need anything. --[[User:Whiteknight|Whiteknight]] <small>([[User talk:Whiteknight|talk]]) ([[User:Whiteknight/Proposed Books|projects]])</small> 02:43, 6 September 2006 (UTC)
---- Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to help you get started: * You can sign your name on Talk and vote pages using four tildes, like this: ~~~~. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * Check out our [[Wikibooks:Help|help]] page if you need additional help. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] * See [[Wikibooks:Template messages|list of templates]] which can save your time * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You can find more resources in the [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Staff lounge|Staff lounge]], or the [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]].
Good luck!. --[[User:Az1568|Az1568]] 03:45, 6 September 2006 (UTC)
== Help and Etiquette ==
I'm glad to hear about your project, wikibooks has hosted a number of collaborative teaching projects, such as [[Human Physiology]], [[CPCN]], and [[XML]]. The [[The Computer Revolution]] book is definately in need of some love and care, so I am happy that your class is working on it.
As to etiquette (and I am sure i'm spelling that incorrectly), there isn't much to worry about, so long as your [[Wikibooks:Be nice|students are nice]]. If you need help, we have a (mostly complete) [[Help:Contents|help book]] available, to learn all the specifics about wikitext markup, page editing, etc. If you or anybody in your class need anything else, please don't hesitate to ask me anything. --[[User:Whiteknight|Whiteknight]] <small>([[User talk:Whiteknight|talk]]) ([[User:Whiteknight/Proposed Books|projects]])</small> 14:50, 6 September 2006 (UTC)
== Page moves ==
Hello Areil, how are things going?
I see that you've been moving some pages around, and while I hate to be the bearer of bad news, I have to inform you that you are moving them wrong. When you move a page, you should specify the destination address in "wikistyle", not as a URL. For instance, you should move pages to:
[[The Computer Revolution/introduction/effect on society/health]]
and not to:
[[Http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/The Computer Revolution/introduction/effect on society/health]]
I will fix the pages that you have already moved for you. If you have any questions, please let me know. --[[User:Whiteknight|Whiteknight]] <small>([[User talk:Whiteknight|talk]]) ([[User:Whiteknight/Proposed Books|projects]])</small> 13:28, 11 September 2006 (UTC)
:You can make a link to a local page by using two square brackets: <nowiki>[[The Computer Revolution/introduction/effect on society/health]]</nowiki> makes: [[The Computer Revolution/introduction/effect on society/health]].
:And you can rename a link to whatever you want it to be: <nowiki>[[The Computer Revolution/introduction/effect on society/health|HEALTH]]</nowiki> makes: [[The Computer Revolution/introduction/effect on society/health|HEALTH]].
:If you want to make a sub-page off a given page, you can just say: [[/sub page/]], and the software will automatically make the link as if you had typed [[User:Areil123/sub page/]]. --[[User:Whiteknight|Whiteknight]] <small>([[User talk:Whiteknight|talk]]) ([[User:Whiteknight/Proposed Books|projects]])</small> 21:10, 11 September 2006 (UTC)
== Page Move Corrections ==
I fixed your bad page moves. When you move a page, DO NOT MOVE IT TO "http://..." This is wrong. Instead, just move it to the name of the page you want. For instance, do not move a page to <nowiki>http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/The Computer Revolution/page</nowiki>, instead, move it to "The Computer Revolution/page". The server will automatically fill in the rest.
If you have any more questions, let me know. If you want a page moved, and you aren't sure how to do it correctly, send me a message, and I will do it for you. Also, when you leave a comment somewhere, you can sign your name to it by typing <nowiki>"~~~~"</nowiki> (four tildes). The server will automaticall replace that with your username. --[[User:Whiteknight|Whiteknight]] <small>([[User talk:Whiteknight|talk]]) ([[User:Whiteknight/Proposed Books|projects]])</small> 18:44, 13 September 2006 (UTC)
== Your Book ==
Sorry It has taken me so long to reply to you, I've been very busy lately. I have seen your book, and with the exception of a few problems with page links, the book looks good. I would like to point you to a page that the community and I have been writing: [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]]. This is just a draft now, but I hope that you can learn things from it, and that eventually you can add your thoughts to it as well. Please let me know if you need anything else. Good luck with your project. --[[User:Whiteknight|Whiteknight]] <small>([[User talk:Whiteknight|talk]]) ([[User:Whiteknight/Proposed Books|projects]])</small> 03:33, 4 December 2006 (UTC)
:By the way, we have also started a page at [[Wikibooks:List of class projects]], where you can list your class project, make comments about it, and ask for help. --[[User:Whiteknight|Whiteknight]] <small>([[User talk:Whiteknight|talk]]) ([[User:Whiteknight/Proposed Books|projects]])</small> 03:39, 4 December 2006 (UTC)
== Using images from Commons ==
G'day, I just found your local copy of a mitochondria image from Commons, [[:Image:Diagram of a human mitochondrion.svg]]. When an image is hosted on Commons, you can use it directly within your Wikibook without having to upload it here. Just put in the image name as if it was a local image, and the wiki software will do the rest for you. [[User:Webaware|Webaware]] <sup>[[User_talk:Webaware|talk]]</sup> 06:24, 27 August 2007 (UTC)
== [[Realpedia]] ==
This book is up for deletion at [[WB:VFD#Realpedia]]. Since you're the primary contributor, please comment and vote on it's deletion. ''' – [[User:Mike.lifeguard|<font color="Indigo">Mike.lifeguard</font>]]''' | <sup>[[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|<font color="Indigo">talk</font>]]</sup> 18:40, 5 September 2007 (UTC)
:I see that you're planning on using this for your family's homeschooling. But what is the book supposed to be? If it's going to be a random collection of facts (which is what it is now... albeit only 2 of them), then that's not a textbook. [[WB:WIW#What Wikibooks Includes|Wikibooks is for textbooks]]; if you need help to determine whether [[Realpedia]] is going to fit within our project's scope, please [[WB:SLN|ask]]. :Please lay out the scope of the book and at least a rudimentary outline so we know whether to delete it (if outside project scope) or not. The main issue is not the lack of content, but rather that there is no organization, no indication that it will be developed into a ''textbook'' and no indication of planning. Just because [[WB:WIW#Wikibooks is not a free wiki host or webspace provider|you're going to fill it with content]] doesn't mean we can keep it here. ''' – [[User:Mike.lifeguard|<font color="Indigo">Mike.lifeguard</font>]]''' | <sup>[[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|<font color="Indigo">talk</font>]]</sup> 12:00, 6 September 2007 (UTC)
:: Everything is on-topic ''someplace''. The trick is finding that place. :: I'm pretty sure that, contrary to popular belief, most books are written by collecting a bunch of random information that the author is interested in. Only afterward does the author shuffle the order of that information, and cut out things that don't seem to "fit" (saving them for the next book), to give the appearance of organization. :: If, like most book authors, you can't create a rough draft of an outline ahead of time, then wikibooks is not the best place to start writing -- there are lots of other places that are better places to begin incubate your "realpedia". I found it pretty easy to create a new wiki on one of the free wiki hosts ([[Wiki_Science/How_to_start_a_Wiki#Free_wiki_hosting]]). Perhaps you could consider creating a new wiki on one of those free hosts, and temporarily moving "realpedia" there. Later once you've filled it out a bit and have an outline, you could move some or all of it back to Wikibooks (if it's a book) or some other more appropriate wiki. :: Is there any way I can help? --[[User:DavidCary|DavidCary]] 05:00, 10 October 2007 (UTC) :: p.s. I'm also encouraging all homeschoolers to check out http://nanowrimo.org/ . --[[User:DavidCary|DavidCary]] 05:00, 10 October 2007 (UTC)

====Please consider creating an account==== ==Welcome!== [[Help:Welcome, newcomers|Welcome to Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks! You don't have to [[Special:Userlogin|log in]] to read or edit articles on Wikibooks, but creating an account is quick, free and non-intrusive, requires no personal information, and gives you many benefits, including: *The use of a username of your choice *The ability to view all your contributions via a "My contributions" link *Your own [[wikipedia:user page|user page]] *Your own talk page which, if you choose, also allows users to send you messages without knowing your e-mail address *The use of your own personal [[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]] to which you can add articles that interest you *The ability to rename pages. *The ability to [[Special:Upload|upload images]] *The ability to customize the appearance and behavior of the website *The eligibility to become an [[Help:Administrators|administrator]] *The right to be heard in votes and elections *Your IP address will no longer be visible to other users.
We hope that you choose to become a Wikibookian and '''[[Special:Userlogin|create an account]]'''. By the way, make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes ('''~~~~'''), which will let others know who left it.. [[User:Az1568|Az1568]] 04:17, 6 September 2006 (UTC)

Thanks for experimenting with the page [[:Puzzles/Four 4's equal/solution]] on Wikibooks. Your test worked, and has been reverted or removed. Take a look at the [[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome page]] if you would like to learn more about contributing to our project. ====Please consider creating an account==== ==Welcome!== [[Help:Welcome, newcomers|Welcome to Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks! You don't have to [[Special:Userlogin|log in]] to read or edit articles on Wikibooks, but creating an account is quick, free and non-intrusive, requires no personal information, and gives you many benefits, including: *The use of a username of your choice *The ability to view all your contributions via a "My contributions" link *Your own [[wikipedia:user page|user page]] *Your own talk page which, if you choose, also allows users to send you messages without knowing your e-mail address *The use of your own personal [[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]] to which you can add articles that interest you *The ability to rename pages. *The ability to [[Special:Upload|upload images]] *The ability to customize the appearance and behavior of the website *The eligibility to become an [[Help:Administrators|administrator]] *The right to be heard in votes and elections *Your IP address will no longer be visible to other users.
We hope that you choose to become a Wikibookian and '''[[Special:Userlogin|create an account]]'''. By the way, make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes ('''~~~~'''), which will let others know who left it.. [[User:Az1568|Az1568]] 04:17, 6 September 2006 (UTC)

page.title: Ukrainian Dancing/Central Ukraine/Steps for Women and Girls

revision.text:
<!--Аа Бб Вв Гг Ґґ Дд Ее Єє Жж Зз Ии Іі Її Йй Кк Лл Мм Нн Оо Пп Рр Сс Тт Уу Фф Хх Цц Чч Шш Щщ Юю Яя Ьь--> To add to this page, go to [[../../Template:Steps | Template:Steps]]. Click on ''edit this page'', and then highlight and copy the entire template. Return to this page and click on ''edit this page''. Go to the end of the page and paste the template. Update the template with your description of the steps.
== Quarter Turns == {| border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" ! Ukrainian Name | Dorizhka v Povoroti |- ! Cyrillic | Доріжка в Повороті |- ! English Name | Quarter Turns |- ! Direction of the Step | Stationary |- ! Music | One complete rotation over four beats. Count is 1-and. |- ! Opening Position | Third or Fifth position. Step is performed on the balls of both feet. |}
=== Description === # Before the first count, turn head to the right, fixing eyes on a spot on the wall. At the same time, raise up on to the ball of the left foot and pivot on the left foot one quarter turn, so that the body is in line with the head. The right foot should be slightly off of the ground, toes pointed downward. # On '''one''' lower the left foot, keeping the heel off of the ground. Place the right foot fully on the ground in an open third or fifth position (i.e., the heel of the right foot is in line with the arch or toe of the left foot. Toes are turned out, but not at an extreme 180 degree turnout). # On '''and''' turn head to the right, fixing eyes on a spot on the wall. At the same time, raise up on to the ball of the left foot and pivot on the left foot one quarter turn, so that the body is in line with the head. The right foot should be slightly off of the ground, toes pointed downward. The dancer should now be turned 180 degrees from the starting point. # On '''two ''' lower the left foot, keeping the heel off of the ground. Place the right foot fully on the ground in an open third or fifth position. # On '''and''' turn head to the right, fixing eyes on a spot on the wall. At the same time, raise up on to the ball of the left foot and pivot on the left foot one quarter turn, so that the body is in line with the head. The right foot should be slightly off of the ground, toes pointed downward. # On '''three''' lower the left foot, keeping the heel off of the ground. Place the right foot fully on the ground in an open third or fifth position. # On '''and''' turn head to the right, fixing eyes on a spot on the wall. At the same time, raise up on to the ball of the left foot and pivot on the left foot one quarter turn, so that the body is in line with the head. The right foot should be slightly off of the ground, toes pointed downward. The dancer should now have returned to the starting position. # On '''four''' lower the left foot, keeping the heel off of the ground. Place the right foot fully on the ground in an open third or fifth position.
The step may also be performed turning over the left shoulder by reversing the working and supporting legs.
== Half Turns == {| border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" ! Ukrainian Name | |- ! Cyrillic | |- ! English Name | Half Turns |- ! Direction of the Step | Stationary |- ! Music | One complete rotation over two beats. Count is 1-and. |- ! Opening Position | Third or Fifth position. Step is performed on the balls of both feet. |}
=== Description === # Before the first count, turn head to look over the right shoulder, fixing eyes on a spot on the wall behind the dancer. At the same time, raise up on to the ball of the left foot and pivot on the left foot one half turn, so that the body is in line with the head. The right foot should be slightly off of the ground, toes pointed downward. The dancer should now be turned 180 degrees from the starting point. # On '''one''' lower the left foot, keeping the heel off of the ground. Place the right foot fully on the ground in an open third or fifth position (i.e., the heel of the right foot is in line with the arch or toe of the left foot. Toes are turned out, but not at an extreme 180 degree turnout). # On '''and''' turn head to look over the right shoulder, fixing eyes on a spot on the wall behind the dancer. At the same time, raise up on to the ball of the left foot and pivot on the left foot one half turn, so that the body is in line with the head. The right foot should be slightly off of the ground, toes pointed downward. The dancer has now returned to the starting point. # On '''two ''' lower the left foot, keeping the heel off of the ground. Place the right foot fully on the ground in an open third or fifth position.
The step may also be performed turning over the left shoulder by reversing the working and supporting legs.
== Prepadanya == {| border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" ! Ukrainian Name | Prepadanya |- ! Cyrillic | |- ! English Name | Prepadanya |- ! Direction of the Step | Travelling sideways |- ! Music | One step per beat. Count is 1-and. |- ! Opening Position | Third or Fifth position. Step is performed on the balls of both feet. |}
=== Description === # Before the first beat, extend the right foot out towards the side. # One '''one''', shift weight onto the right foot, placing the entire foot on the ground. Raise the left foot and bring it behind the right ankle. # On '''and''', step onto the ball of the left foot, and extend the right foot out towards the side.
The step may also be performed towards the left.
== Toe-Heel - turning == {| border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" ! Ukrainian Name | |- ! Cyrillic | |- ! English Name | Toe-heel with a turn |- ! Direction of the Step | Turning |- ! Music | One rotation over two beats. |- ! Opening Position | Sixth position. |}
=== Description === # One '''one''', hop and place the toe of the right foot behind the dancer. # On '''and''', hop and pivot 180 degrees on the left foot, turning over the right shoulder. At the same time, turn the right foot up, so that the heel is on the ground and the toe is facing upwards. The dancer has completed one half rotation.
To complete the rotation, the dancer can perform another toe-heel half-turn, or another step, such as pokhid skladnye.
The step may also be performed towards the left.
{{BookCat}}

{{A Beginner's Guide to D}} [[Image:BeginnersDSm.jpg|200px|left]] == For Experienced Programmers == '''D''' is very similar to languages like C++ and Java. Therefore, if you have experience with those languages, you can probably pick up D by simply reading the [[/D Transition Guide/]]. == Status of this Text == This book will be a guide to people starting to program using the D programming language. It is intended for a range of audiences, from people new to programming to the seasoned programmer. The book has been arranged so that you can follow the suggested chapter order, which will lead you through the concepts such that you can use them before finishing the book. Alternatively, you can select the chapters as you see fit, skipping over some things that you might already be familiar with. This book does not include a comprehensive introduction to programming as there are many sources for that already, though it does have a [[/Short Introduction to Programming/|''refresher'']] on the topic. The content of this book is based on the use of the Phobos standard library which comes with the DigitalMars dmd compiler. Before contributing, please read the [[/Style Guide/]]. : The Table of Contents is almost done, so this book is now open for content. If you want to write a page, first read the [[/Style Guide/]], then choose a page, replace the text in the list below with a link to the name you want like so: 
[[/Chapter/]] or [[/Chapter/Section Title/|Section Title]]
(The /'s are important), and put some note on the page to say you're going to handle it (to try to minimize duplication). == Table of Contents == (These titles are not final, and beyond chapter 2 they're not even good titles. Before making a page, please give it a good title) # [[/Before We Begin.../]] ## [[/Before We Begin.../Short Introduction to D|Short Introduction to D]] ## [[/Before We Begin.../D Compiler|D Compiler]] ## [[/Before We Begin.../Editors Supporting D|Editors Supporting D]] # [[/The Basics/]] ## [[/The Basics/The Structure of D/|The Structure of D]] ## [[/The Basics/Start at the Beginning/|Start at the Beginning]] ## [[/The Basics/Introduction to Modules/|Introduction to Modules]] ## [[/The Basics/Types and Math/|Types and Math]] [input of a few different types, up to dynamic arrays] ## [[/The Basics/Basic Output/|Basic Output]] [using std.stdio.writef/writefln] ## [[/The Basics/Basic Input/|Basic Input]] [using std.cstream.din] # [[/Conditions and Loops/]] ## [[/Conditions and Loops/The Concepts of Conditionals and Loops/|The Concepts of Conditionals and Loops]] ## [[/Conditions and Loops/Simple Branching/|Simple Branching]] ## [[/Conditions and Loops/Simple Iteration/|Simple Iteration]] ## [[/Conditions and Loops/Simple Looping/|Simple Looping]] (The while and do-while loops) ## [[/Conditions and Loops/Complex Iteration: The for Loop/|Complex Iteration]] (The for Loop) ## [[/Conditions and Loops/Switch Statement/]] (The Switch conditional) # Functions and Simple Arguments [somewhere in this chapter, segfaults and other failures should be briefly introduced but simply refer to a later chapter] ## The Concept of Functions [NOT in the Functional Programming sense] ## Simple Functions ## Recursion ## Passing Basic Types ## Passing Arrays ## Assertion and Contracts # Basic Classes and Object Orientation ## The Concept of Classes ## Simple Classes [an extension to the input programs above that has a "person" class with char[] name, int age, etc.] ## Methods ## Data Hiding ### Public vs Private ### Accessor Methods and Properties # Exceptions and Handling [This chapter should also mention segmentation faults] ## The Concept of Exceptions ## Throwing Exceptions ## Simple Catching ## The finally Clause # Advanced Arrays ## Dynamic Arrays, Concatenation and COW ## Static Arrays ## Associative Arrays # Modules ## Modules and the Filesystem ## Making your Own Modules ## Importing Modules ### Public vs private vs static imports ### Namespace and Conflicts # Advanced Object Orientation ## Friendly Classes ## Class Inheritance ### Simple Inheritance ### Interfaces ## Operator Overloading ##x. --- TO BE COMPLETED --- # Advanced Functions and Arguments [This chapter should perhaps be switched with the last one] ## Review of Passing ## Passing Classes ## Passing by-val vs. by-ref: in, out, inout ##x. Function Pointers and Delegates? ##x. --- TO BE COMPLETED --- # [[/Templates and Generic Programming/]] ## [[/Templates and Generic Programming/Template Classes/|Template Classes]] ## [[/Templates and Generic Programming/Template Functions/|Template Functions]] ## [[/Templates and Generic Programming/Mixins/|Mixins]] ## [[/Templates and Generic Programming/Advanced Templates/|Advanced Templates]] # Miscellaneous and Advanced Features ## Functions ### Lazy Evaluation ## Object Orientation ### Structs and Packing ### Unions ## Enumerations #TO BE CONTINUED ---- Things to be added (in no particular order; feel free to add these yourself): * Preprocessor-like functionality: ** Pragmas ** Conditional Compilation * Mixins ** Probably in the (to-be-described) templates section * Function Pointers and Delegates ** If the Advanced Functions chapter comes after Advanced OO, this fits there. * Garbage Collection ** Not sure where to put this * Scoped statements ** Not sure where to put this * Type-casting ** Needs to be in multiple places * Array literals ** Probably should be in [[/The Basics/Types and Math/]] * Signals and slots * Tuples * 'scope' for object variables * Sockets * Threads {{Subjects|D programming language}} {{Alphabetical|B}} {{status|25%}}
== Summary == A simple cover for A Beginner's Guide to D. (Small version) == Licensing == {{self|cc-by-sa-2.5}}
